body: The show did not pander, fans said. It did not condescend. It showed Brooklyn, they insisted, for what it was -- a place, apparently, with unlicensed private detective work, armies of baby strollers and a bearded superhero whose most salient superpower, acquired after a below-the-belt run-in with the third rail of a subway, cannot be described in a
title: Gathering to Mourn the End of a Show That Celebrated Brooklyn

body: TJ GIRARD believes that most traditional serving vessels could use some spicing up. Parties are ''supposed to be fun, exciting and entertaining,'' she said. title: SHOPPING WITH TJ GIRARD; Pressed Into Service

body: THE tree is glittering in the living room, and garlands are plentiful throughout the house. But people searching for another holiday standard, mistletoe, will be hard pressed this year to find a decent-looking sprig, if they're able to find any at all. There are many species of mistletoe. But the kissing kind that is native to the United States, a
title: Mistletoe Gets the Kiss-Off

body: The traditional Italian Christmas Eve dinner, the Feast of the Seven Fishes, is not exactly Mother's Day, but it gets close, with special fish dinners all over town and not just at Italian restaurants. Here are some choices on and around Dec. 24 (prices do not include beverages, tax or tip). Bistro de la Gare, 626 Hudson Street (Jane Street); (212)
title: Feasting On Fish

body: Television Kathryn Shattuck Admit it: The holidays were made for ogling. The Swarovski crystal star atop the neighbor's 10-foot tree. The ribbon-wrapped Porsche Panamera in the driveway down the block. The lighting extravaganza sapping enough electricity to power a village for a year. And no one does good old-fashioned voyeurism better than HGTV.
title: THE WEEK AHEAD; Dec. 18 -- 24

body: Classical Steve Smith It's a time of year when you start to feel as if you can't cross a street or turn a corner without bumping into a ''Messiah.'' title: The Week Ahead | Dec. 18 - Dec. 24

body: EDUCATING the average drinker on the qualities of firewater, and how to best enjoy it, has been one of the central credos of the new generation of mixologists. ''Knowledge!'' they cry, as they throw back shots of Fernet-Branca. But some booze-addled misconceptions continue to cling to the lizard brain of the American tippler. An army of bartenders
title: HOLIDAY DRINKS; Debunking the Myths Shared at the Bar

title: Camps Are Cleared, but '99 Percent' Still Occupies the Lexicon

body: New Yorkers are fond, perhaps overly so, of assembling ever-creative names for newly hot neighborhoods, from NoMad (north of Madison Square Park) to SoBro (the South Bronx) to BoCoCa (Boerum Hill, Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens). Now comes LoLo -- perhaps the most far-fetched name of all, given that the neighborhood does not actually exist. LoLo,
title: Visions of a Development Rising From the Sea

body: PUPPETS ON FILM They make some of the best colleagues in cinema: hardworking, uncomplaining, malleable, never in need of the Betty Ford Center. And even in small roles they add magic and mystery. Now moviegoers can admire their artistry, and that of their operators, in Puppets on Film, presented by BAMcinématek and the Jim Henson Foundation.
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: LIKE many young married people, Steve and Logan Kinney dream of owning a home. So after several years of diligent saving, the couple, both teachers, scoured the listings in Boerum Hill, the leafy Brooklyn neighborhood where they rented. But before long, they realized that home ownership would require living within the four walls of a studio. And
title: WHICH WAY HOME; A Familiar Dream, Still Beyond Reach

body: 120 Smith Street, Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 852-0200; biencuit.com. The name of the new artisanal bakery on Smith Street, Bien Cuit, translates from the French as ''well done.'' It signifies the way the best artisans believe all bread should be baked: with a dark brown crust to bring out the deep flavors of the grains. So the sign out front
title: DINING BRIEFS | RECENTLY OPENED; Bien Cuit

body: Every fall, thousands of upper-middle-class parents here awake in night sweats, overcome by the anxiety of trying to get their children into costly and prestigious preschools. To say this, of course, is to say something as obvious as ''pork chops cost more at Dean & DeLuca than they do at Key Food.'' Two years ago an entire documentary film,
title: BIG CITY; Burdening Children With a Flawed Policy

body: Warren Street between Bond and Nevins offers many of the things well-off buyers seek in Brownstone Brooklyn: a pastoral, leafy feel; long rows of 19th-century town houses; proximity to transportation and charming little restaurants; young families on the block. But the block also has something that those buyers have traditionally seemed to avoid:
title: THE APPRAISAL; In Brooklyn, A Quaint Block And a Symbol of Blight

body: Meat's Place A panel discussion about the changing role of meat in the American diet will be held Thursday from 4 to 6 p.m. at the Fales Library in the Elmer Holmes Bobst Library of New York University, 70 Washington Square South (La Guardia Place). title: Calendar

body: Amy Finkel lives in an apartment in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, that does not allow pets. But she does have a groundhog (Chompers), an armadillo (Fleischesser) and a boar (Angel). They are all, however, dead and stuffed - and in the case of the boar, it is just the head. ''I do think I have a tendency to anthropomorphize,'' Ms. Finkel said. ''But I'm
title: When Pets Are Dearly Departed, and Staying, Too

body: Assemblyman Hakeem Jeffries, calling Congress a ''swamp of dysfunction,'' has begun accepting contributions for a race against a fellow Democrat, Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn. Mr. Jeffries said he had not made a final decision to run against Mr. Towns, but in late September he filed paperwork that would allow him to proceed as a
title: Assemblyman Appears Ready to Join Race for Congress

title: Spare Times

body: The scarlet letter may have little currency left in the realm of sexual indiscretion, but it continues to be put to vigorous use among parents -- the shaming impulse particularly thrives in the wealthier precincts of brownstone Brooklyn, where the exacting standards of urbane motherhood would seem to have been invented. title: BIG CITY; The Outcast of Brownstone Brooklyn

title: The Listings

body: Anthony Braxton sat perched on a piano bench one recent afternoon, hands folded in his lap, wearing an intent but unreadable expression. Angled away from the piano in a no-frills rehearsal space in Brooklyn, he faced the dozen or so vocalists that currently make up his Syntactical Ghost Trance Music Choir. The singers, arranged in a semicircle,
title: Celebrating a Master Of the Avant-Garde

body: SOME two dozen new condominium developments have just started selling or are scheduled to start sales this fall in New York. Among them are: ONE57 At 157 West 57th Street, this 90-story mixed-use tower, planned as the city's tallest residential structure, will have 135 condo units; one57.com 1 MIMA TOWER On the Far West Side at 460 West 42nd
title: New on the Horizon

body: Like many teachers, Jamie Fidler does not end her workday when her students go home, mainly because she cannot afford to, she says. At 3:30 p.m., when the last class ends, Ms. Fidler, a first-grade teacher at Public School 261 in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, heads to her second job, where she tutors children until 5:30. And three years ago, when she was
title: Film Examines the Challenging Economics Facing Teachers

title: MUSIC REVIEW; Moving to a New Borough and Banking on Name Recognition

title: OP-ED COLUMNIST; Bicycle Visionary

title: ON RELIGION; A Boy's Bar Mitzvah Lessons Bridge a Cultural Chasm

title: DINING BRIEFS | RECENTLY OPENED; Nitehawk Cinema

body: LIKE most MetroCard-carrying New Yorkers, Sara Schwartz normally spends Saturday night flitting about the city. She arrived at a friend's apartment with reinforcements: cheese, prosciutto, bread, wine (she left the
title: A New York Calm Amid the Storm

body: THE separation anxiety test was not going well: Subject barked at the door, charged over to a red rubber toy, raced back to the door, barked again, more loudly this time, and then squatted and left a puddle in front of the door. The frustration test went slightly better, although when the red rubber toy with peanut butter inside rolled under the
title: BIG DEAL; Panting Through The Co-op Interview

body: STEVE SIDDELL paid just $700 a month for his share of the rent on a three-bedroom apartment in Crown Heights. But, at age 32, he felt too old to have roommates. Besides, one of his roommates was allergic to cats, so Mr. Siddell kept his two cats and their litter box in his bedroom, which necessitated installing a door sweep and two air purifiers.
title: THE HUNT; The Post-Roommate Stage

body: THE best posts on the style blog Street Etiquette find its principals, Travis Gumbs and Joshua Kissi, in motion. As opposed to the fascistically frozen street-style snaps of The Sartorialist and others, these pictures are styled and plotted fictions but also affecting ones, depicting a pair of young black men taking ownership not just of the body
title: Serious About Cool

title: Spare Times

title: Back to the Simple Life, With Needle and Thread

title: TALK; DINNER AT 8

title: Weekend Miser

body: L. J. Davis, a journalist and novelist who wrote about money and business, real estate and home renovation, the Industrial Revolution and his beloved Brooklyn, often with wry or sardonic humor, was found dead in his Brooklyn home on Wednesday. He was 70. Judith Rascoe, a friend, confirmed the death. The cause had not yet been determined, she said.
title: L. J. Davis, Journalist and Novelist, Is Dead at 70

title: Spare Times: For Children

title: Troubled Past for Man Charged in a City Officer's Death

body: It was a relatively routine call, the kind that the New York City police usually handle without too much trouble. A frightened woman in Brooklyn telephoned 911 early Sunday morning and reported that her ex-boyfriend was threatening her. ''He said he's going to kill me,'' the woman cried. ''He said he's across the street, and he's going to kill me

body: STEPHEN ANTONSON, an artist with a wily and mischievous point of view, is fond of saying that when he makes something, he'd like that thing to do more than just lie there. He might throw in a sight gag: a plaster bust of Pan wears a cream pie in his face; a ghostly plaster side table erupts into a fruit bowl. Or maybe he'll set up a word pun. Home
title: ON LOCATION; Making It Up As They Go

body: KELLY--Regina, died February 24, 2011 at the Calvary Hospital Hospice. A brilliant, independent and articulate woman, Ms. Kelly was both charming and acerbic. She was employed for many years at Sloan Kettering Hospital and after graduating from Brooklyn Law School was appointed as an Assistant District Attorney in Kings County. Her loss will be
title: Paid Notice: Deaths KELLY, REGINA

body: BEN RYDER HOWE says he was raised to avoid using the personal pronoun ''I'' when writing. Moreover, he rarely wrote about New York. Fortunately for readers, he overcame both disinclinations in his first book, ''My Korean Deli: Risking It All for a Convenience Store'' (Henry Holt, $25). It's a charming, present-tense, only-in-New York chronicle of
title: BOOKSHELF; Adventures in an Urban Wilderness

body: AT his house in New Rochelle, Reginald Johnson cooked and baked in his dream kitchen, where he used a 60-inch-wide Wolf range to make delicacies like butternut squash ravioli and rosemary-olive-oil cake. But when he split with his partner a year and a half ago, he left the house they shared, put most of his belongings in storage, bunked with a
title: THE HUNT; Space for Spices, Gadgets and Guests

body: THE FAT RADISH 17 Orchard Street (Canal Street), Chinatown; (212) 300-4053; thefatradishnyc.com. A spare loftlike restaurant on lower Orchard Street with a beautiful crowd and a menu that is British after a fashion, rustic at that, lighter than its promise, often more flavorful. The dining room is beautiful and airy, a space that might have been a
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: $8.5 MILLION 351 Atlantic Avenue (between Hoyt and Bond Streets) Boerum Hill, Brooklyn This four-story loft building offers two floors of retail space that is owner-occupied by an antiques dealer and two upper floors of residential space. The building is to be delivered vacant. Owner: Donald Gianchetta Brokers: Geoffrey M. Rand and Paul J. Nigido,
title: TRANSACTIONS; For Sale

body: David Cay Johnston's article about the new tax law appears in today's Wealth special section, and he is taking readers' questions. This post will be updated with more answers as the day progresses, the most recent appearing on top. Send your tax questions to specialsections@nytimes.com. Q.Can you still give up to $100,000 from your Individual
title: SPECIAL SECTION: WEALTH; Answers to Your Tax Questions

body: THE world has a dust problem. There is more of it than there used to be. Apparently, the amount of airborne dust doubled in the 20th century, according to a recent scientific paper in the journal Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics. The claim sounds outlandish. The amount of dust in the world -- like the amount of sin or acne -- must be a constant.
title: Speck By Speck, It Piles Up

body: EARLY evening at Mile End, and the air is heady with the scent of meat. A few breaths, and the head swims. It is unsubtle, reckless, potentially ruinous. A vegetarian, accidentally stumbling by, might wake up the next morning and not remember a thing. Mile End opened a year ago in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, and has been standing room only ever since.
title: $25 AND UNDER; The Jewish Deli Gets a Makeover

author: E-mail: appraisal@nytimes.com
body: For six months, Emily Huters and her husband, Trey Hatch, spent five hours every Sunday morning taking turns caring for their son, Henry, so they could clean up their loft for open houses. They packed up Henry's play mat and toys, tried to remove smashed raisins from every crevice of his highchair and moved his hefty nursing chair to a neighbor's
title: THE APPRAISAL; Have an Open House Every Sunday? Or Play With Henry?

body: Opening EMBER ROOM No longer associated with Kittichai in SoHo, Ian Chalermkittichai has gone back to using his full surname. Now he has teamed with Todd English to create Asian-inflected barbecue in a space sheathed in dark reclaimed boards, some looking as if they came from a wood pile out back. A special oven is the centerpiece between the bar
title: Off the Menu

body: THE bad news first: Walking down the northern stretch of Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, you will still have to squint very hard to see it as the borough's version of Park Avenue in Manhattan. That comparison, which boosters have been making in recent years as the corridor has come to life, is still aspirational -- especially so against the backdrop of
title: LIVING ON | FOURTH AVENUE, BROOKLYN; New Cityscape, in Search of Green Space

body: Eduardo Espirito Santo, a sociable graduate of the University of Richmond who comes from a prominent Portuguese banking family, would seem like a stable enough tenant. Even in a slow economy, he landed a summer internship at the Atlantic Council in Washington and this month started a second internship at a financial firm in New York City. But these
title: THE APPRAISAL; The Long Ordeal of Landing a Short-Term Rental

body: BOERUM HILL ROW HOUSE $1,495,000 BROOKLYN: 237 Wyckoff Street (between Nevins and Bond Streets) A 17-foot-wide 19th-century house with three bedrooms, two baths, a garden, a washer and dryer, and a full basement with a wine cellar. Sue Wolfe (917) 868-5332, James Crow (917) 902-7119, Corcoran Group; www.corcoran.com Open house Sunday, 1 to 3 p.m.
title: ON THE MARKET

body: OUIGI THEODORE, the founder of the Brooklyn Circus, a retro-urban fashion boutique and label, has heard it all before: dandy, preppy, Anglophile, fop. Still, he was flummoxed when a customer walked into his boutique a year ago, took one look at the bow ties and straw boaters for sale, and declared it the height of ''steampunk.'' Mr. Theodore, 35,
title: UP CLOSE; The Bearded Dandy of Brooklyn

body: FOR eight years, Brendan Mason had a great apartment in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. His one-bedroom rental was in an owner-occupied brownstone with endless prewar charm. On the stoop one flight down, he would drink coffee, socialize with neighbors, have a smoke. His rent was less than $1,500 a month. His partner, Matthew Reuter, had a less compelling
title: THE HUNT; Room for Men to Work and for Astro to Play
